body: lets change app infos, fixed migration so it creates things the "right" way.  changed app infos
LGTM.
Why not use a whitelist such as [-_A-Za-z0-9] ?
I used an exclusion list rather than a white list to allow for non-English characters in the application name. If other languages are not supported, we could change it to a white list.
Collections are also affected

From RFC 3986:
      2.3.  Unreserved Characters
      Characters that are allowed in a URI but do not have a reserved
      purpose are called unreserved.  These include uppercase and lowercase
      letters, decimal digits, hyphen, period, underscore, and tilde.

```
  unreserved  = ALPHA / DIGIT / "-" / "." / "_" / "~"
```

So an organisation/application/collection should only contain this characters.
Do not merge yet.  I need to perform more integration testing with existing clusters.
This is a huge change. It might be a good idea to do a screen-sharing session with a couple of UG devs and walk through the design and code.
LGTM. Feel free to merge

Based on feedback from rgex, I am now using a whitelist that includes the unreserved characters. I found that I cannot use JAX-RS path param regexp URI matching because the matching is done before URI decoding.

I would suggest that we check the organization, application, collection and connection names.
Similar to CouchDB I think that we should allow ALPHA / DIGIT / "-" / "." / "_" / "~" with one exception: names starting with underscore would be system reserved.

Yeah, I agree, a peer review would be ideal.  We're still doing performance testing.  Once we're happy with that, we should review everything.  I want to make sure this is performant before we push it through.

@tnine Please take another look. I made flatmap max observables match write thread count and use Schedulers.io() instead of a custom readScheduler.  But I had to keep the writeScheduler in place, otherwise my test fails because (I think) threads explode and Cassandra falls over -- also, the write scheduler allows us to constrain the number of files produced by the tool.

I see that Lynch Lee is working on USERGRID-868 and has a pull request open for validating entity names. @rgex Should we merge this pull request and let Lynch Lee take care of collection and connection names?
Already merged into the code base.  Closing.

I've merged this, if there's more content to add please raise more PRs.  The more the merrier.

@tnine this test fails intermittently on the build server.  what do you think about adding delay in here to make it more consistent?

why not just say (_next !== null && _next !== undefined) 
not sure we want to propagate !! around
also have you signed an apache icla?
+1, we don't want to change this in 1.0, there's a lot of internal indexing behavior that depends on it.

Sorry, I have not signed anything. The readme mentions "For larger PRs" and I didn't think this would be considered a large pull request.

Using `!!` is concise and covers all falsey values, including `_next` set to an empty string. I don't know if that's possible or not with the `fetch` request on line 1760, but it seemed like the safest bet.
Not yet ready to merge.  Please review and comment.

The existing IntersectionTransitivePagingIT looks good, but it tests a more simple query, one that intersection two slice iterators -- so it did not tickle this bug.  

I think we are ready to merge this into 1.x. If we want more complex query tests we should open up a new JIRA for that.
Ignore, wrong branch :(

This happens synchronous to the write commit, adding more write ops to the path when ... since it's not used anywhere now, looks we need to get it in soon to prevent wide rows in that CF.  However, we should spend time in master to see if we can make this an async event for deleting old versions of a unique value.

:+1: 
I'll merge, then validate the CORS fix.
+1.  This looks ready to merge

I think we need to address this in 2 ways.

1) This should fire an asynchronous task.

2) Create multiple scheduler instances of the RxTaskScheduler.  1 for async queue processing. 1 for collections.

This is done.  We need to implement read-repair on field seek to ensure that values exist and match the entity.  Unfortunately we can't guarantee consistency since repair runs after write commit and before returning to the caller.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/USERGRID-921

Looks good overall, but why do we need to disable read-repairs?

If we have to disable read repairs we should mark the tests that fail (see below) with the Ignore annotation and a comment that explains it.

Failed tests:
  ServiceRequestIT.testRepairOfSingleEntity:160 Create call should have worked
  ServiceRequestIT.testRepairOfMultipleEntitiesAndRemainingEntities:313 null
Read repair is being temporarily removed until we can test/validate further.  Good catch on the tests.  Fixing that now.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/USERGRID-1187
